Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
There are more than one and a half billion
people out there using the internet every day, and just like you, they're looking for
answers. We here at SciShow are looking for answers
too, answers to questions about science and nature and the human body, Earth and the universe! So we're working with Google and YouTube to
answer ten of the most popular questions searched for on the internet. This is the World's Most Asked Questions! [Intro] Today’s question is: How can I get rid of
hiccups? People have all kinds of hiccup remedies that
they swear by, none of which seem to have much to do with each other -- like, swallowing
a teaspoon of sugar, or guzzling a glass of water, or just holding your breath. But to figure out how to get rid of hiccups
-- and why we get them in the first place -- you gotta start with getting to know your
diaphragm. The diaphragm is a sheet of muscle under your
lungs that is one of the most important muscles you have, if you enjoy things like breathing. And a hiccup is just an involuntary spasm
of the diaphragm that causes it to contract suddenly. When that happens, you take in a gulp of air
really quickly, until your vocal folds -- the membranes at the top of your throat -- clamp
shut. That’s what causes the “hic” sound. Most of the time, the spasm stops as quickly
as it started, and you can just say “excuse me” and get on with your life. But sometimes, those spasms won’t stop ... which
means it’s time to get your diaphragm to relax. To do this, you basically gotta hit the reset
button on your nervous system -- or at least the part that controls your diaphragm. You can do that in a couple of different ways. One is to stimulate your vagus nerve -- that's
a nerve that runs down your neck from the base of your brain, and it regulates some
of your body’s most important functions, including your heartbeat and your breathing. Basically, you need to stimulate this nerve
-- distract it, if you will -- so it’ll stop constantly zapping your diaphragm. So, some people have luck getting rid of hiccups
by swallowing a teaspoon of sugar. Sounds delicious, but it’s harder than it
sounds. The act of gulping down those dry granules
can provide just enough confusing stimulus for your vagus nerve to start focusing on
your throat, and leave your diaphragm alone. Another more common approach to kicking the
hiccups is to increase the level of carbon dioxide in your bloodstream. That might seem a little weird, but your natural
breathing rhythms are regulated by your CO2 levels, and if they get too high, your nervous
system will signal your diaphragm and lungs to make sure they’re doing their job. And this is what’s behind most of the hiccup-busting
techniques you’ve probably heard of -- like holding your breath, or breathing into a paper
bag, or drinking a tall glass of water. All of that stuff stops your intake of oxygen
and ramps up your internal CO2 concentration, which signals your diaphragm to get its head
in the game and fix things. If the human body weren't so weird, it wouldn't
be so fascinating. And speaking of hiccup cures, of those of
you who filled out our SciShow Survey, 54% said that holding your breath was your preferred
method for relieving hiccups, while at a close second was drinking water, at 37%. We're loving answering these questions, but
of all the questions in the world, what do YOU most want answered? Let us know on Facebook or Twitter or in the
comments down below, and we will answer the best questions in a new video at the end of
the month. Don’t forget to use the hashtag #WMAQ, for
World's Most Asked Questions, and stay tuned for more answers here on SciShow.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why do we hiccup?
Options: A. Our diaphragm causes our vocal folds to involuntarily spasm causing a hiccup., B. Our lungs involuntarily spasm and cause the diaphragm to clamp down., C. Our diaphragm has an involuntary spasm which causes us to take in a sudden gulp of air and our vocal folds clamp shut., D. Our vocal folds involuntarily spasm and cause our lungs to seize and our diaphragm to clamp down.
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the diaphragm, and what is its primary function in the human body? Options: A. A sheet of muscle under the lungs that regulates heartbeat, B. A sheet of muscle under the lungs that is essential for breathing, C. A nerve that runs down the neck from the base of the brain, D. A membrane at the top of the throat that produces sound Correct Option: B
Question 2: What causes the "hic" sound when a person experiences a hiccup? Options: A. The sudden contraction of the diaphragm, B. The stimulation of the vagus nerve, C. The clamping shut of the vocal folds, D. The increase in carbon dioxide levels in the bloodstream Correct Option: C
Question 3: A person is experiencing persistent hiccups. What can they try to "hit the reset button" on their nervous system and relax their diaphragm? Options: A. Holding their breath for an extended period, B. Stimulating their vagus nerve by swallowing a teaspoon of sugar, C. Drinking a tall glass of water to increase oxygen intake, D. Breathing rapidly to decrease carbon dioxide levels Correct Option: B
Question 4: According to the SciShow Survey, what is the most preferred method for relieving hiccups? Options: A. Drinking water, B. Holding your breath, C. Swallowing a teaspoon of sugar, D. Breathing into a paper bag Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the primary function of the vagus nerve in the human body? Options: A. To regulate breathing and heartbeat, B. To control the diaphragm and lungs, C. To produce sound through the vocal folds, D. To stimulate the nervous system Correct Option: A
Question 6: A person is trying to get rid of hiccups by increasing the level of carbon dioxide in their bloodstream. Which of the following techniques is most likely to achieve this? Options: A. Breathing rapidly to increase oxygen intake, B. Holding their breath for an extended period, C. Drinking a tall glass of water to increase oxygen intake, D. Swallowing a teaspoon of sugar to stimulate the vagus nerve Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the relationship between carbon dioxide levels and breathing rhythms in the human body? Options: A. High CO2 levels signal the diaphragm and lungs to slow down, B. Low CO2 levels signal the diaphragm and lungs to speed up, C. High CO2 levels signal the diaphragm and lungs to make sure they're doing their job, D. Low CO2 levels signal the diaphragm and lungs to relax Correct Option: C
Question 8: A person is experiencing persistent hiccups and tries several remedies without success. What may be the underlying cause of their hiccups? Options: A. A malfunctioning vagus nerve, B. A problem with their diaphragm, C. An imbalance in their carbon dioxide levels, D. A combination of factors, including a spasmodic diaphragm and an overactive vagus nerve Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the purpose of the World's Most Asked Questions series, and how can viewers participate? Options: A. To answer the most popular questions searched for on the internet, and viewers can participate by filling out a survey, B. To provide information on various scientific topics, and viewers can participate by asking questions on social media, C. To promote the SciShow channel, and viewers can participate by sharing their favorite episodes, D. To educate viewers on health-related topics, and viewers can participate by submitting their questions through a comments section Correct Option: A
Question 10: Why do people experience hiccups, and what is the primary muscle involved in this process? Options: A. People experience hiccups due to a malfunctioning vagus nerve, and the primary muscle involved is the diaphragm, B. People experience hiccups due to an imbalance in their carbon dioxide levels, and the primary muscle involved is the diaphragm, C. People experience hiccups due to a spasmodic contraction of the diaphragm, and the primary muscle involved is the diaphragm, D. People experience hiccups due to a problem with their vocal folds, and the primary muscle involved is the larynx Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 10. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent (why do people hiccup?), options (focusing on the diaphragm and its role in hiccuping), and content (explaining the primary muscle involved in hiccuping). The correct option for Question 10 (C) also aligns with the correct option for the ground truth MCQ (C), which states that hiccups occur due to an involuntary spasm of the diaphragm.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 10

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
There are more than one and a half billion
people out there using the internet every day, and just like you, they're looking for
answers. We here at SciShow are looking for answers
too, answers to questions about science and nature and the human body, Earth and the universe! So we're working with Google and YouTube to
answer ten of the most popular questions searched for on the internet. This is the World's Most Asked Questions! [Intro] Today’s question is: How can I get rid of
hiccups? People have all kinds of hiccup remedies that
they swear by, none of which seem to have much to do with each other -- like, swallowing
a teaspoon of sugar, or guzzling a glass of water, or just holding your breath. But to figure out how to get rid of hiccups
-- and why we get them in the first place -- you gotta start with getting to know your
diaphragm. The diaphragm is a sheet of muscle under your
lungs that is one of the most important muscles you have, if you enjoy things like breathing. And a hiccup is just an involuntary spasm
of the diaphragm that causes it to contract suddenly. When that happens, you take in a gulp of air
really quickly, until your vocal folds -- the membranes at the top of your throat -- clamp
shut. That’s what causes the “hic” sound. Most of the time, the spasm stops as quickly
as it started, and you can just say “excuse me” and get on with your life. But sometimes, those spasms won’t stop ... which
means it’s time to get your diaphragm to relax. To do this, you basically gotta hit the reset
button on your nervous system -- or at least the part that controls your diaphragm. You can do that in a couple of different ways. One is to stimulate your vagus nerve -- that's
a nerve that runs down your neck from the base of your brain, and it regulates some
of your body’s most important functions, including your heartbeat and your breathing. Basically, you need to stimulate this nerve
-- distract it, if you will -- so it’ll stop constantly zapping your diaphragm. So, some people have luck getting rid of hiccups
by swallowing a teaspoon of sugar. Sounds delicious, but it’s harder than it
sounds. The act of gulping down those dry granules
can provide just enough confusing stimulus for your vagus nerve to start focusing on
your throat, and leave your diaphragm alone. Another more common approach to kicking the
hiccups is to increase the level of carbon dioxide in your bloodstream. That might seem a little weird, but your natural
breathing rhythms are regulated by your CO2 levels, and if they get too high, your nervous
system will signal your diaphragm and lungs to make sure they’re doing their job. And this is what’s behind most of the hiccup-busting
techniques you’ve probably heard of -- like holding your breath, or breathing into a paper
bag, or drinking a tall glass of water. All of that stuff stops your intake of oxygen
and ramps up your internal CO2 concentration, which signals your diaphragm to get its head
in the game and fix things. If the human body weren't so weird, it wouldn't
be so fascinating. And speaking of hiccup cures, of those of
you who filled out our SciShow Survey, 54% said that holding your breath was your preferred
method for relieving hiccups, while at a close second was drinking water, at 37%. We're loving answering these questions, but
of all the questions in the world, what do YOU most want answered? Let us know on Facebook or Twitter or in the
comments down below, and we will answer the best questions in a new video at the end of
the month. Don’t forget to use the hashtag #WMAQ, for
World's Most Asked Questions, and stay tuned for more answers here on SciShow.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is a diaphragm?
Options: A. A small muscle in between your lungs that is one of the most important muscles for breathing., B. A sac of air pockets that live inside your lung and are most important for breathing., C. A nerve that runs from the base of your skull down your spine and is important for breathing., D. A sheet of muscle underneath your lungs that is one of the most important muscles for breathing.
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the diaphragm, and what is its primary function in the human body? Options: A. A sheet of muscle under the lungs that regulates heartbeat, B. A sheet of muscle under the lungs that is essential for breathing, C. A nerve that runs down the neck from the base of the brain, D. A membrane at the top of the throat that produces sound Correct Option: B
Question 2: What causes the "hic" sound when a person experiences a hiccup? Options: A. The sudden contraction of the diaphragm, B. The stimulation of the vagus nerve, C. The clamping shut of the vocal folds, D. The increase in carbon dioxide levels in the bloodstream Correct Option: C
Question 3: A person is experiencing persistent hiccups. What can they try to "hit the reset button" on their nervous system and relax their diaphragm? Options: A. Holding their breath for an extended period, B. Stimulating their vagus nerve by swallowing a teaspoon of sugar, C. Drinking a tall glass of water to increase oxygen intake, D. Breathing rapidly to decrease carbon dioxide levels Correct Option: B
Question 4: According to the SciShow Survey, what is the most preferred method for relieving hiccups? Options: A. Drinking water, B. Holding your breath, C. Swallowing a teaspoon of sugar, D. Breathing into a paper bag Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the primary function of the vagus nerve in the human body? Options: A. To regulate breathing and heartbeat, B. To control the diaphragm and lungs, C. To produce sound through the vocal folds, D. To stimulate the nervous system Correct Option: A
Question 6: A person is trying to get rid of hiccups by increasing the level of carbon dioxide in their bloodstream. Which of the following techniques is most likely to achieve this? Options: A. Breathing rapidly to increase oxygen intake, B. Holding their breath for an extended period, C. Drinking a tall glass of water to increase oxygen intake, D. Swallowing a teaspoon of sugar to stimulate the vagus nerve Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the relationship between carbon dioxide levels and breathing rhythms in the human body? Options: A. High CO2 levels signal the diaphragm and lungs to slow down, B. Low CO2 levels signal the diaphragm and lungs to speed up, C. High CO2 levels signal the diaphragm and lungs to make sure they're doing their job, D. Low CO2 levels signal the diaphragm and lungs to relax Correct Option: C
Question 8: A person is experiencing persistent hiccups and tries several remedies without success. What may be the underlying cause of their hiccups? Options: A. A malfunctioning vagus nerve, B. A problem with their diaphragm, C. An imbalance in their carbon dioxide levels, D. A combination of factors, including a spasmodic diaphragm and an overactive vagus nerve Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the purpose of the World's Most Asked Questions series, and how can viewers participate? Options: A. To answer the most popular questions searched for on the internet, and viewers can participate by filling out a survey, B. To provide information on various scientific topics, and viewers can participate by asking questions on social media, C. To promote the SciShow channel, and viewers can participate by sharing their favorite episodes, D. To educate viewers on health-related topics, and viewers can participate by submitting their questions through a comments section Correct Option: A
Question 10: Why do people experience hiccups, and what is the primary muscle involved in this process? Options: A. People experience hiccups due to a malfunctioning vagus nerve, and the primary muscle involved is the diaphragm, B. People experience hiccups due to an imbalance in their carbon dioxide levels, and the primary muscle involved is the diaphragm, C. People experience hiccups due to a spasmodic contraction of the diaphragm, and the primary muscle involved is the diaphragm, D. People experience hiccups due to a problem with their vocal folds, and the primary muscle involved is the larynx Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

Although the question phrasing is slightly different, both the ground truth MCQ and Question 1 are asking about the definition and primary function of the diaphragm. The correct options in both questions (D in the ground truth MCQ and B in Question 1) accurately describe the diaphragm as a sheet of muscle under the lungs that is essential for breathing.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
There are more than one and a half billion
people out there using the internet every day, and just like you, they're looking for
answers. We here at SciShow are looking for answers
too, answers to questions about science and nature and the human body, Earth and the universe! So we're working with Google and YouTube to
answer ten of the most popular questions searched for on the internet. This is the World's Most Asked Questions! [Intro] Today’s question is: How can I get rid of
hiccups? People have all kinds of hiccup remedies that
they swear by, none of which seem to have much to do with each other -- like, swallowing
a teaspoon of sugar, or guzzling a glass of water, or just holding your breath. But to figure out how to get rid of hiccups
-- and why we get them in the first place -- you gotta start with getting to know your
diaphragm. The diaphragm is a sheet of muscle under your
lungs that is one of the most important muscles you have, if you enjoy things like breathing. And a hiccup is just an involuntary spasm
of the diaphragm that causes it to contract suddenly. When that happens, you take in a gulp of air
really quickly, until your vocal folds -- the membranes at the top of your throat -- clamp
shut. That’s what causes the “hic” sound. Most of the time, the spasm stops as quickly
as it started, and you can just say “excuse me” and get on with your life. But sometimes, those spasms won’t stop ... which
means it’s time to get your diaphragm to relax. To do this, you basically gotta hit the reset
button on your nervous system -- or at least the part that controls your diaphragm. You can do that in a couple of different ways. One is to stimulate your vagus nerve -- that's
a nerve that runs down your neck from the base of your brain, and it regulates some
of your body’s most important functions, including your heartbeat and your breathing. Basically, you need to stimulate this nerve
-- distract it, if you will -- so it’ll stop constantly zapping your diaphragm. So, some people have luck getting rid of hiccups
by swallowing a teaspoon of sugar. Sounds delicious, but it’s harder than it
sounds. The act of gulping down those dry granules
can provide just enough confusing stimulus for your vagus nerve to start focusing on
your throat, and leave your diaphragm alone. Another more common approach to kicking the
hiccups is to increase the level of carbon dioxide in your bloodstream. That might seem a little weird, but your natural
breathing rhythms are regulated by your CO2 levels, and if they get too high, your nervous
system will signal your diaphragm and lungs to make sure they’re doing their job. And this is what’s behind most of the hiccup-busting
techniques you’ve probably heard of -- like holding your breath, or breathing into a paper
bag, or drinking a tall glass of water. All of that stuff stops your intake of oxygen
and ramps up your internal CO2 concentration, which signals your diaphragm to get its head
in the game and fix things. If the human body weren't so weird, it wouldn't
be so fascinating. And speaking of hiccup cures, of those of
you who filled out our SciShow Survey, 54% said that holding your breath was your preferred
method for relieving hiccups, while at a close second was drinking water, at 37%. We're loving answering these questions, but
of all the questions in the world, what do YOU most want answered? Let us know on Facebook or Twitter or in the
comments down below, and we will answer the best questions in a new video at the end of
the month. Don’t forget to use the hashtag #WMAQ, for
World's Most Asked Questions, and stay tuned for more answers here on SciShow.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How do we stop hiccups?
Options: A. We have to tell our diaphragm to stop hiccupping., B. We have to hit the reset button on our nervous system and get our diaphragm to relax., C. We have to stimulate our diaphragm more to make it change the hiccups., D. We can't stop hiccups, they stop themselves.
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the diaphragm, and what is its primary function in the human body? Options: A. A sheet of muscle under the lungs that regulates heartbeat, B. A sheet of muscle under the lungs that is essential for breathing, C. A nerve that runs down the neck from the base of the brain, D. A membrane at the top of the throat that produces sound Correct Option: B
Question 2: What causes the "hic" sound when a person experiences a hiccup? Options: A. The sudden contraction of the diaphragm, B. The stimulation of the vagus nerve, C. The clamping shut of the vocal folds, D. The increase in carbon dioxide levels in the bloodstream Correct Option: C
Question 3: A person is experiencing persistent hiccups. What can they try to "hit the reset button" on their nervous system and relax their diaphragm? Options: A. Holding their breath for an extended period, B. Stimulating their vagus nerve by swallowing a teaspoon of sugar, C. Drinking a tall glass of water to increase oxygen intake, D. Breathing rapidly to decrease carbon dioxide levels Correct Option: B
Question 4: According to the SciShow Survey, what is the most preferred method for relieving hiccups? Options: A. Drinking water, B. Holding your breath, C. Swallowing a teaspoon of sugar, D. Breathing into a paper bag Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the primary function of the vagus nerve in the human body? Options: A. To regulate breathing and heartbeat, B. To control the diaphragm and lungs, C. To produce sound through the vocal folds, D. To stimulate the nervous system Correct Option: A
Question 6: A person is trying to get rid of hiccups by increasing the level of carbon dioxide in their bloodstream. Which of the following techniques is most likely to achieve this? Options: A. Breathing rapidly to increase oxygen intake, B. Holding their breath for an extended period, C. Drinking a tall glass of water to increase oxygen intake, D. Swallowing a teaspoon of sugar to stimulate the vagus nerve Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the relationship between carbon dioxide levels and breathing rhythms in the human body? Options: A. High CO2 levels signal the diaphragm and lungs to slow down, B. Low CO2 levels signal the diaphragm and lungs to speed up, C. High CO2 levels signal the diaphragm and lungs to make sure they're doing their job, D. Low CO2 levels signal the diaphragm and lungs to relax Correct Option: C
Question 8: A person is experiencing persistent hiccups and tries several remedies without success. What may be the underlying cause of their hiccups? Options: A. A malfunctioning vagus nerve, B. A problem with their diaphragm, C. An imbalance in their carbon dioxide levels, D. A combination of factors, including a spasmodic diaphragm and an overactive vagus nerve Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the purpose of the World's Most Asked Questions series, and how can viewers participate? Options: A. To answer the most popular questions searched for on the internet, and viewers can participate by filling out a survey, B. To provide information on various scientific topics, and viewers can participate by asking questions on social media, C. To promote the SciShow channel, and viewers can participate by sharing their favorite episodes, D. To educate viewers on health-related topics, and viewers can participate by submitting their questions through a comments section Correct Option: A
Question 10: Why do people experience hiccups, and what is the primary muscle involved in this process? Options: A. People experience hiccups due to a malfunctioning vagus nerve, and the primary muscle involved is the diaphragm, B. People experience hiccups due to an imbalance in their carbon dioxide levels, and the primary muscle involved is the diaphragm, C. People experience hiccups due to a spasmodic contraction of the diaphragm, and the primary muscle involved is the diaphragm, D. People experience hiccups due to a problem with their vocal folds, and the primary muscle involved is the larynx Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

This question aligns with the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, which is to identify a method to stop hiccups by relaxing the diaphragm. The correct option in Question 3, "Stimulating their vagus nerve by swallowing a teaspoon of sugar," is a specific example of how to "hit the reset button" on the nervous system, as mentioned in the correct option of the ground truth MCQ. 

Although the options are not identical, the underlying concept and solution to the problem of persistent hiccups are the same, making Question 3 the most similar generated MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
There are more than one and a half billion
people out there using the internet every day, and just like you, they're looking for
answers. We here at SciShow are looking for answers
too, answers to questions about science and nature and the human body, Earth and the universe! So we're working with Google and YouTube to
answer ten of the most popular questions searched for on the internet. This is the World's Most Asked Questions! [Intro] Today’s question is: How can I get rid of
hiccups? People have all kinds of hiccup remedies that
they swear by, none of which seem to have much to do with each other -- like, swallowing
a teaspoon of sugar, or guzzling a glass of water, or just holding your breath. But to figure out how to get rid of hiccups
-- and why we get them in the first place -- you gotta start with getting to know your
diaphragm. The diaphragm is a sheet of muscle under your
lungs that is one of the most important muscles you have, if you enjoy things like breathing. And a hiccup is just an involuntary spasm
of the diaphragm that causes it to contract suddenly. When that happens, you take in a gulp of air
really quickly, until your vocal folds -- the membranes at the top of your throat -- clamp
shut. That’s what causes the “hic” sound. Most of the time, the spasm stops as quickly
as it started, and you can just say “excuse me” and get on with your life. But sometimes, those spasms won’t stop ... which
means it’s time to get your diaphragm to relax. To do this, you basically gotta hit the reset
button on your nervous system -- or at least the part that controls your diaphragm. You can do that in a couple of different ways. One is to stimulate your vagus nerve -- that's
a nerve that runs down your neck from the base of your brain, and it regulates some
of your body’s most important functions, including your heartbeat and your breathing. Basically, you need to stimulate this nerve
-- distract it, if you will -- so it’ll stop constantly zapping your diaphragm. So, some people have luck getting rid of hiccups
by swallowing a teaspoon of sugar. Sounds delicious, but it’s harder than it
sounds. The act of gulping down those dry granules
can provide just enough confusing stimulus for your vagus nerve to start focusing on
your throat, and leave your diaphragm alone. Another more common approach to kicking the
hiccups is to increase the level of carbon dioxide in your bloodstream. That might seem a little weird, but your natural
breathing rhythms are regulated by your CO2 levels, and if they get too high, your nervous
system will signal your diaphragm and lungs to make sure they’re doing their job. And this is what’s behind most of the hiccup-busting
techniques you’ve probably heard of -- like holding your breath, or breathing into a paper
bag, or drinking a tall glass of water. All of that stuff stops your intake of oxygen
and ramps up your internal CO2 concentration, which signals your diaphragm to get its head
in the game and fix things. If the human body weren't so weird, it wouldn't
be so fascinating. And speaking of hiccup cures, of those of
you who filled out our SciShow Survey, 54% said that holding your breath was your preferred
method for relieving hiccups, while at a close second was drinking water, at 37%. We're loving answering these questions, but
of all the questions in the world, what do YOU most want answered? Let us know on Facebook or Twitter or in the
comments down below, and we will answer the best questions in a new video at the end of
the month. Don’t forget to use the hashtag #WMAQ, for
World's Most Asked Questions, and stay tuned for more answers here on SciShow.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How does swallowing a spoonful of sugar help stop hiccups?
Options: A. Swallowing sugar is hard. It confuses the Vagus Nerve and makes it start concentrating on your throat swallowing which leave the diaphragm alone., B. Swallowing sugar is too sweet. It refocuses the Vagus Nerve on the incredible sweetness which leaves the diaphragm alone., C. Swallowing sugar stimulates your vocal folds and causes them to relax., D. Swallowing sugar causes your body to inhale a large amount of oxygen which calms your diaphragm.
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the diaphragm, and what is its primary function in the human body? Options: A. A sheet of muscle under the lungs that regulates heartbeat, B. A sheet of muscle under the lungs that is essential for breathing, C. A nerve that runs down the neck from the base of the brain, D. A membrane at the top of the throat that produces sound Correct Option: B
Question 2: What causes the "hic" sound when a person experiences a hiccup? Options: A. The sudden contraction of the diaphragm, B. The stimulation of the vagus nerve, C. The clamping shut of the vocal folds, D. The increase in carbon dioxide levels in the bloodstream Correct Option: C
Question 3: A person is experiencing persistent hiccups. What can they try to "hit the reset button" on their nervous system and relax their diaphragm? Options: A. Holding their breath for an extended period, B. Stimulating their vagus nerve by swallowing a teaspoon of sugar, C. Drinking a tall glass of water to increase oxygen intake, D. Breathing rapidly to decrease carbon dioxide levels Correct Option: B
Question 4: According to the SciShow Survey, what is the most preferred method for relieving hiccups? Options: A. Drinking water, B. Holding your breath, C. Swallowing a teaspoon of sugar, D. Breathing into a paper bag Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the primary function of the vagus nerve in the human body? Options: A. To regulate breathing and heartbeat, B. To control the diaphragm and lungs, C. To produce sound through the vocal folds, D. To stimulate the nervous system Correct Option: A
Question 6: A person is trying to get rid of hiccups by increasing the level of carbon dioxide in their bloodstream. Which of the following techniques is most likely to achieve this? Options: A. Breathing rapidly to increase oxygen intake, B. Holding their breath for an extended period, C. Drinking a tall glass of water to increase oxygen intake, D. Swallowing a teaspoon of sugar to stimulate the vagus nerve Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the relationship between carbon dioxide levels and breathing rhythms in the human body? Options: A. High CO2 levels signal the diaphragm and lungs to slow down, B. Low CO2 levels signal the diaphragm and lungs to speed up, C. High CO2 levels signal the diaphragm and lungs to make sure they're doing their job, D. Low CO2 levels signal the diaphragm and lungs to relax Correct Option: C
Question 8: A person is experiencing persistent hiccups and tries several remedies without success. What may be the underlying cause of their hiccups? Options: A. A malfunctioning vagus nerve, B. A problem with their diaphragm, C. An imbalance in their carbon dioxide levels, D. A combination of factors, including a spasmodic diaphragm and an overactive vagus nerve Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the purpose of the World's Most Asked Questions series, and how can viewers participate? Options: A. To answer the most popular questions searched for on the internet, and viewers can participate by filling out a survey, B. To provide information on various scientific topics, and viewers can participate by asking questions on social media, C. To promote the SciShow channel, and viewers can participate by sharing their favorite episodes, D. To educate viewers on health-related topics, and viewers can participate by submitting their questions through a comments section Correct Option: A
Question 10: Why do people experience hiccups, and what is the primary muscle involved in this process? Options: A. People experience hiccups due to a malfunctioning vagus nerve, and the primary muscle involved is the diaphragm, B. People experience hiccups due to an imbalance in their carbon dioxide levels, and the primary muscle involved is the diaphragm, C. People experience hiccups due to a spasmodic contraction of the diaphragm, and the primary muscle involved is the diaphragm, D. People experience hiccups due to a problem with their vocal folds, and the primary muscle involved is the larynx Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

This question has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, as it asks about a method to stop hiccups. The correct option in Question 3 (B. Stimulating their vagus nerve by swallowing a teaspoon of sugar) is similar to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ (A. Swallowing sugar is hard. It confuses the Vagus Nerve and makes it start concentrating on your throat swallowing which leave the diaphragm alone.). Both options mention swallowing sugar and its effect on the vagus nerve in relation to stopping hiccups. 

While the wording is not identical, the content and intent of Question 3 are the most similar to the ground truth MCQ among the provided generated MCQs. 

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
[Music] Hey there, engineer buddies! I just want to thank you so much
for helping out in the last episode. I needed to get my phone out of the storm
drain, and together, we designed a solution. Our robot was just one of many possible solutions, and maybe you had an even better idea at home. If you did, please send it my way.
I'd love to check it out! But I've got a whole new challenge for you. Have you ever just wanted
some space to yourself? A place to relax, do your own thing,
eat Nutella straight off your fingers, and burp with abandon? Yeah, I need that.
That is a thing I need. You know what can help? I bet you already guessed it! Engineering. So how do we use the engineering
process to solve this problem? [Music] Well, first, we've got to define the problem. I need a place that is secluded and quiet. I need it to provide privacy
and a sense of my-ownness. Sounds pretty great, right? What about a big box to use as my space? It's secluded and it can be all my own. Solution-wise, it's a start, but a small one. We need to consider more options. What if I made adjustments to a
space I already have: my room? I could hang blankets from the ceiling
to help block out sounds from outside, and then I could also sing my
head off to T Swift if I wanted to without bothering the rest of my family. To top things off, I could add
a "Do Not Enter" sign to my door. Like, a serious sign. 
Bold font, all caps. Respect my sign! Okay, we've got two options. What else? What if instead of adjusting a space
I already have, I create a new space? There's a word for what we're
talking about here: architecture. Maybe we could become not just engineers,
but architects: engineers who design buildings. Even though the title of the job is a little
different, the process is still the same. So before doing architecture, we've got to weigh our options and choose
the best design to take into trials. Let's think about the box idea first. It's probably too small. I'd either be squished or
be half hanging out of it. Okay, how about tricking out my room? Again, while I'd feel like I have a sense
of privacy, I'd know that at any point, any one of my family members could bust in, and the blankets on the walls 
would muffle some of the sound, but wouldn't totally block them out. But hey, here's an idea:
what about a tree house? It would be totally my own, it would be far enough from my house that any weird burps or loud renditions
of "Shake It Off" wouldn't bug my family. Of course, it would take some
work. Some architecture work. So architect, activate!  [Music] Let's build the treehouse! It'll have a drop-down rope ladder that
I can pull up for optimal privacy, and it'll have windows so I can spot
when someone's on the way over and properly prepare myself. I can even use the blanket wall idea from
my second proposal to muffle the sound. Of course, I'll need space for lounging
and reading and dancing around, but before we start building,
you know what we've got to do? Build the prototype and test it. And in order to conduct useful trials,
we need to isolate the variables. What are the variables of
this particular mission? The size of the treehouse we choose
and the weight of the treehouse are really important variables
because we gotta make sure the treehouse can stay in the tree. What about variables when it comes
to soundproofing the thing? The number and the size of the
blankets that I use would be one, and so would be the amount of noise
I plan on making inside the treehouse. And we have to keep in
mind failure points, too. Like, the tree might be able to support
little old me in a small wooden tree house, but if I have a friend or two over,
the load might be too heavy. That would be a serious failure point. As for keeping things nice and quiet,
maybe my thickest heaviest blankets can block a soft rendition
of "You Belong With Me," but they might fail when I belt out
"Shake It Off" or have a burping contest. You've gotta test these things! So we'll keep working with the variables
until we've got a working design. Then, it's time to build. [Music] Architects use the same process,
the engineering process, when planning buildings from
skyscrapers to small family homes. I came up with what I think
will be a great treehouse, but as always, there can be lots
of different successful solutions. So here's your challenge: can you come
up with your own architecture solution? What would your building look like? How would it meet the success
criteria and navigate the variables? Let us know! [Music]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In the video, we see that one failure point is if she builds a treehouse, she may be able to stay in but can't have friends over. What is a failure point?
Options: A. A place where a solution to a problem fails., B. A place where a solution to a problem has limits., C. A place where a solution to a problem causes a collapse in the solution., D. A place where a solution to the problem causes another unknown variable.
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the challenge presented in the previous episode that required designing a solution? Options: A. Retrieving a phone from a storm drain, B. Building a treehouse, C. Creating a private space, D. Designing a skyscraper Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is the main goal of the challenge presented in this episode? Options: A. To design a new phone, B. To create a private space for relaxation, C. To build a robot, D. To plan a city Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the first step in the engineering process to solve the problem of needing a private space? Options: A. Building a prototype, B. Defining the problem, C. Testing variables, D. Creating a design Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is one possible solution to creating a private space that was discussed in the episode? Options: A. Building a new room in the house, B. Hanging blankets from the ceiling to block out sounds, C. Creating a "Do Not Enter" sign for the door, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 5: What field of study involves designing buildings, and is closely related to engineering? Options: A. Architecture, B. Physics, C. Mathematics, D. Computer Science Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is one potential problem with using a box as a private space? Options: A. It would be too expensive, B. It would be too small, C. It would be too loud, D. It would be too heavy Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the purpose of isolating variables when testing a prototype? Options: A. To make the design more complicated, B. To reduce the cost of the project, C. To ensure accurate and reliable test results, D. To make the design more aesthetically pleasing Correct Option: C
Question 8: What are two important variables to consider when building a treehouse? Options: A. Size and color, B. Weight and height, C. Size and weight, D. Material and shape Correct Option: C
Question 9: Why is it important to test a design for potential failure points? Options: A. To make sure it is perfect, B. To identify and fix potential problems before they occur, C. To make the design more complicated, D. To reduce the cost of the project Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the final step in the engineering process after testing and refining a design? Options: A. Building the prototype, B. Testing variables, C. Creating a design, D. Building the final product Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 9. 

Although the question content is not identical, the intent and options of Question 9 align with the ground truth MCQ. Both questions focus on the concept of failure points in the engineering process. The ground truth MCQ asks for the definition of a failure point, while Question 9 asks why it's essential to test for potential failure points. The correct options in both questions convey the idea that failure points are limitations or potential problems in a solution that need to be identified and addressed.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Hey, today we are going to have fun with learning
about Black History and a man named Malcolm X. With Black History in the United States, many
African-Americans mention Malcolm X. Do you know who Malcolm X is? Malcolm X was an African-American Civil Rights
Activist and Minister. Right now we will learn a little bit about
his life. Malcolm X was born Malcolm Little on May 19,
1925 in Omaha, Nebraska. Malcolm was the fourth of eight children born
to Louise, a homemaker, and Earl Little, a preacher. His father spoke out against racism and was
often picked on by a group named the Ku Klux Klan. It was so bad the littles had to move from
Omaha and his father was later found murdered. After the death of Malcolm’s father, Malcolm's
mother became very sick and could not take care of her children. This is where Malcolm and his siblings were
placed in foster care. Seeing all of this Malcolm would get into
trouble later on finding himself in a juvenile detention center, and later on finding himself
in prison after getting in trouble. It was there his life would change when he
discovered a religion known as Islam. After choosing the religion of Islam and joining
the Nation of Islam, Malcolm Little would soon change his name from to Malcolm X, where
he would go on to be a well-known leader of the Nation of Islam. During this time another African-American
Civil Rights Activist was Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Although Dr. King spoke about peaceful protests,
Malcolm X was known for saying, “By any means necessary,” and "You don't have to
have a peaceful revolution," when speaking against racism. Malcolm X would later leave the Nation of
Islam and become a traditional Muslim where he changed his name to El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz. Malcolm X’s life came to an end after he
was assassinated on February 21, 1965, in New York, New York. That is all for me and I hope you enjoyed
learning about Black History and Malcolm X a civil rights activist and preacher. I hope you had fun learning with F.R.E.S.B.E.R.G
cartoon.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: While Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X approached the Civil Rights Movement differently, they did have two things in common. What were they?
Options: A. They were both ministers and they both grew up in Nebraska., B. They were both ministers and they were both assassinated., C. They were both assassinated and they both found religion as adults., D. Both had sick mothers who died and fathers that were ministers.
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was Malcolm X's birth name? Options: A. Malcolm X, B. El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz, C. Malcolm Little, D. Earl Little Correct Option: C
Question 2: What was the main reason for the Little family's frequent moves during Malcolm's childhood? Options: A. Financial difficulties, B. Earl Little's preaching schedule, C. The Ku Klux Klan's harassment, D. Louise Little's health issues Correct Option: C
Question 3: What event in Malcolm's life led to his discovery of the Islam religion? Options: A. His father's death, B. His mother's illness, C. His time in a juvenile detention center, D. His imprisonment Correct Option: D
Question 4: What was the primary difference between Malcolm X's and Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s approaches to fighting racism? Options: A. Malcolm X focused on peaceful protests, while Dr. King advocated for violent revolution, B. Malcolm X believed in non-violent resistance, while Dr. King supported armed struggle, C. Malcolm X was willing to use any means necessary, while Dr. King advocated for peaceful protests, D. Malcolm X focused on economic empowerment, while Dr. King focused on social justice Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was the name of the organization that Malcolm X joined and later became a leader of? Options: A. Nation of Islam, B. Ku Klux Klan, C. Civil Rights Movement, D. Black Panther Party Correct Option: A
Question 6: What was the significance of Malcolm X's name change from Malcolm Little to Malcolm X? Options: A. It marked his conversion to Christianity, B. It symbolized his rejection of his family's values, C. It represented his new identity as a member of the Nation of Islam, D. It was a way to distance himself from his father's legacy Correct Option: C
Question 7: If you were a civil rights activist in the 1960s, would you have been more likely to follow Malcolm X's or Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s approach to fighting racism? Why or why not? (This question requires application and evaluation skills, as it asks the test-taker to consider their own values and approach to social justice.) Options: A. Malcolm X's approach, because it emphasized the need for immediate action and radical change, B. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s approach, because it emphasized the importance of non-violent resistance and gradual progress, C. Neither approach, because they both had limitations and flaws, D. Both approaches, because they complemented each other and offered different strategies for different situations Correct Option: None
Question 8: How did Malcolm X's life experiences shape his views on racism and social justice? Options: A. His experiences with racism and violence led him to advocate for peaceful protests and non-violent resistance, B. His experiences with poverty and inequality led him to focus on economic empowerment and social welfare programs, C. His experiences with the Ku Klux Klan and police brutality led him to believe in the need for armed self-defense and radical action, D. His experiences with the Nation of Islam and traditional Islam led him to emphasize the importance of spiritual transformation and personal growth Correct Option: C
Question 9: What was the significance of Malcolm X's later name change from Malcolm X to El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz? Options: A. It marked his rejection of the Nation of Islam and his adoption of traditional Islam, B. It symbolized his newfound commitment to non-violent resistance and peaceful protests, C. It represented his attempt to distance himself from his past and start a new life, D. It was a way to honor his father's legacy and continue his work Correct Option: A
Question 10: How did Malcolm X's assassination affect the Civil Rights Movement? Options: A. It led to a decline in activism and a loss of momentum for the movement, B. It sparked widespread outrage and protests, leading to increased mobilization and activism, C. It had little impact on the movement, as Malcolm X was no longer a prominent leader at the time of his death, D. It led to a shift in the movement's focus from social justice to economic empowerment Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4. 

Although Question 4 does not directly ask about the commonalities between Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X, it does address their differing approaches to fighting racism, which is a key aspect of the ground truth MCQ. However, none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ.

If I had to choose the most similar one based on the content and intent, I would choose Question 4, as it is the only one that mentions both Malcolm X and Martin Luther King Jr. and discusses their approaches to fighting racism.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 4

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Hey, today we are going to have fun with learning
about Black History and a man named Malcolm X. With Black History in the United States, many
African-Americans mention Malcolm X. Do you know who Malcolm X is? Malcolm X was an African-American Civil Rights
Activist and Minister. Right now we will learn a little bit about
his life. Malcolm X was born Malcolm Little on May 19,
1925 in Omaha, Nebraska. Malcolm was the fourth of eight children born
to Louise, a homemaker, and Earl Little, a preacher. His father spoke out against racism and was
often picked on by a group named the Ku Klux Klan. It was so bad the littles had to move from
Omaha and his father was later found murdered. After the death of Malcolm’s father, Malcolm's
mother became very sick and could not take care of her children. This is where Malcolm and his siblings were
placed in foster care. Seeing all of this Malcolm would get into
trouble later on finding himself in a juvenile detention center, and later on finding himself
in prison after getting in trouble. It was there his life would change when he
discovered a religion known as Islam. After choosing the religion of Islam and joining
the Nation of Islam, Malcolm Little would soon change his name from to Malcolm X, where
he would go on to be a well-known leader of the Nation of Islam. During this time another African-American
Civil Rights Activist was Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Although Dr. King spoke about peaceful protests,
Malcolm X was known for saying, “By any means necessary,” and "You don't have to
have a peaceful revolution," when speaking against racism. Malcolm X would later leave the Nation of
Islam and become a traditional Muslim where he changed his name to El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz. Malcolm X’s life came to an end after he
was assassinated on February 21, 1965, in New York, New York. That is all for me and I hope you enjoyed
learning about Black History and Malcolm X a civil rights activist and preacher. I hope you had fun learning with F.R.E.S.B.E.R.G
cartoon.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What was Malcom X's last name when he was born?
Options: A. Smart, B. X, C. Little, D. Johnson
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 3

**Transcript**:
Hey, today we are going to have fun with learning
about Black History and a man named Malcolm X. With Black History in the United States, many
African-Americans mention Malcolm X. Do you know who Malcolm X is? Malcolm X was an African-American Civil Rights
Activist and Minister. Right now we will learn a little bit about
his life. Malcolm X was born Malcolm Little on May 19,
1925 in Omaha, Nebraska. Malcolm was the fourth of eight children born
to Louise, a homemaker, and Earl Little, a preacher. His father spoke out against racism and was
often picked on by a group named the Ku Klux Klan. It was so bad the littles had to move from
Omaha and his father was later found murdered. After the death of Malcolm’s father, Malcolm's
mother became very sick and could not take care of her children. This is where Malcolm and his siblings were
placed in foster care. Seeing all of this Malcolm would get into
trouble later on finding himself in a juvenile detention center, and later on finding himself
in prison after getting in trouble. It was there his life would change when he
discovered a religion known as Islam. After choosing the religion of Islam and joining
the Nation of Islam, Malcolm Little would soon change his name from to Malcolm X, where
he would go on to be a well-known leader of the Nation of Islam. During this time another African-American
Civil Rights Activist was Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Although Dr. King spoke about peaceful protests,
Malcolm X was known for saying, “By any means necessary,” and "You don't have to
have a peaceful revolution," when speaking against racism. Malcolm X would later leave the Nation of
Islam and become a traditional Muslim where he changed his name to El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz. Malcolm X’s life came to an end after he
was assassinated on February 21, 1965, in New York, New York. That is all for me and I hope you enjoyed
learning about Black History and Malcolm X a civil rights activist and preacher. I hope you had fun learning with F.R.E.S.B.E.R.G
cartoon.

Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 4

**Transcript**:
Hey, today we are going to have fun with learning
about Black History and a man named Malcolm X. With Black History in the United States, many
African-Americans mention Malcolm X. Do you know who Malcolm X is? Malcolm X was an African-American Civil Rights
Activist and Minister. Right now we will learn a little bit about
his life. Malcolm X was born Malcolm Little on May 19,
1925 in Omaha, Nebraska. Malcolm was the fourth of eight children born
to Louise, a homemaker, and Earl Little, a preacher. His father spoke out against racism and was
often picked on by a group named the Ku Klux Klan. It was so bad the littles had to move from
Omaha and his father was later found murdered. After the death of Malcolm’s father, Malcolm's
mother became very sick and could not take care of her children. This is where Malcolm and his siblings were
placed in foster care. Seeing all of this Malcolm would get into
trouble later on finding himself in a juvenile detention center, and later on finding himself
in prison after getting in trouble. It was there his life would change when he
discovered a religion known as Islam. After choosing the religion of Islam and joining
the Nation of Islam, Malcolm Little would soon change his name from to Malcolm X, where
he would go on to be a well-known leader of the Nation of Islam. During this time another African-American
Civil Rights Activist was Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Although Dr. King spoke about peaceful protests,
Malcolm X was known for saying, “By any means necessary,” and "You don't have to
have a peaceful revolution," when speaking against racism. Malcolm X would later leave the Nation of
Islam and become a traditional Muslim where he changed his name to El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz. Malcolm X’s life came to an end after he
was assassinated on February 21, 1965, in New York, New York. That is all for me and I hope you enjoyed
learning about Black History and Malcolm X a civil rights activist and preacher. I hope you had fun learning with F.R.E.S.B.E.R.G
cartoon.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

Although the question content is not identical, both questions address the negative impact of the Ku Klux Klan (KKK) on Malcolm X's life. The ground truth MCQ specifically asks about the KKK causing a major event in Malcolm's life, while Question 2 asks about the main reason for the Little family's frequent moves during Malcolm's childhood. However, the correct option for Question 2 (C. The Ku Klux Klan's harassment) is closely related to the correct option for the ground truth MCQ (A. They killed his father), as the KKK's harassment is mentioned in the transcript as a factor that led to the Little family's moves and ultimately to the death of Malcolm's father.

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 2.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The evil wizard MoldeVort 
has been trying to kill you for years, and today it looks like 
he’s going to succeed. But your friends are on their way, 
and if you can survive until they arrive, they should be able to help stop him. The evil wizard’s protective charms 
ward off every spell you know, so in an act of desperation 
you throw the only object in reach at him: Pythagoras’s cursed chessboard. It works, but with a catch. MoldeVort starts in one corner 
of the 5x5 board. You have a few minutes to choose 
four distinct positive whole numbers. MoldeVort gets to say one of them, 
and if you can pick a square on the board whose center is exactly 
that distance away, the curse will force him 
to move to that spot. Then he’ll have to choose 
any of the four numbers, and the process repeats until 
you can’t keep him inside the board with legal moves. Then he’ll break free of the spell 
and almost certainly kill you. What four numbers can you choose 
to keep MoldeVort trapped by your spell long enough for help to arrive? 
And what’s your strategy? Pause the video to figure it out yourself. Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 The trick here is to keep MoldeVort 
where you want him. And one way to figure out how to do that is to play out the game 
as MoldeVort would: always trying to escape. You’re dealing with a relatively 
small board, so the numbers can’t be too big. Let’s start by trying 1, 2, 3, 4 
to see what happens. Moldevort could escape those numbers
in just three moves. By saying 2, then 3, he would force you to let him into one
of the middle points of the grid, and then a 4 would break him free. But that means you’ll need to allow
a number larger than 4, which is the distance from one end 
of a row to another. How is that even possible? Through diagonal moves. There are, in fact, points that are 
distance 5 from each other, which we know thanks 
to the Pythagorean Theorem. That states that the squares 
of the sides of a right triangle add up to the square of its hypotenuse. One of the most famous 
Pythagorean triples is 3, 4, 5, and that triangle is hiding all over 
your chessboard. So if MoldeVort was here, and he said 5,
you could move him to these spaces. There’s another insight that will help. The board is very symmetrical: 
If MoldeVort is in a corner, it doesn’t really matter 
to you which corner it is. So we can think of the corners 
as being functionally the same, and color them all blue. Similarly, the spaces neighboring 
the corners behave the same as each other, and we’ll make them red. Finally, the midpoints of the sides 
are a third type. So instead of having to develop a strategy for each of the 16 spaces 
on the outside of the board, we can reduce the problem to just three. Meanwhile, all the inside spaces 
are bad for us, because if MoldeVort ever reaches one, he’ll be able to say any number 
larger than 3 and go free. Orange spaces are trouble too, 
since any number except 1, 2, or 4 would take him to an inside space 
or off the board. So orange is out and you’ll need 
to keep him on blue and red. That means 2 is bad, since it could take MoldeVort 
to orange on the first turn. But the four other smallest numbers, 
1, 3, 4, and 5, might work. Let’s try them and see what happens. If MoldeVort says 1, you can make 
him go from blue to red or red to blue. And the same works if he says 3. Thanks to our diagonals, 
this is even true if he says 5. If he says 4, you can keep him 
on the color he’s already on by moving the length of a row or column. So these four numbers work! Even if your friends don’t get here 
right away, you’ll be able to keep 
the world’s most evil wizard contained for as long as you need.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What are the dimensions of the cursed chessboard?
Options: A. 4 by 4, B. 5 by 5, C. 6 by 6, D. 8 by 8
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary goal of the scenario described in the transcript? Options: A. To defeat the evil wizard MoldeVort in a game of chess, B. To keep MoldeVort trapped on a 5x5 chessboard using a curse, C. To solve a mathematical puzzle to escape a magical trap, D. To understand the principles of the Pythagorean Theorem Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the name of the theorem mentioned in the transcript that helps in determining distances on the chessboard? Options: A. Pythagorean Theorem, B. Euclidean Theorem, C. Diagonal Theorem, D. Geometric Theorem Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the minimum number of distinct positive whole numbers required to keep MoldeVort trapped on the chessboard? Options: A. 2, B. 3, C. 4, D. 5 Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the strategy employed to simplify the problem of dealing with 16 spaces on the outside of the board? Options: A. Dividing the board into smaller sections, B. Color-coding the spaces based on their behavior, C. Focusing on the center of the board, D. Ignoring the corners of the board Correct Option: B
Question 5: Why are the inside spaces on the board considered "bad" for the player? Options: A. Because MoldeVort can move freely in any direction, B. Because MoldeVort can say any number larger than 3 and escape, C. Because the player cannot move MoldeVort to those spaces, D. Because the spaces are too far away from the corners Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the result of MoldeVort saying the number 5, according to the transcript? Options: A. The player can move MoldeVort to any space on the board, B. The player can move MoldeVort to a space that is 5 units away, C. The player can move MoldeVort to a space that is 3 or 4 units away, D. The player cannot move MoldeVort at all Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the set of numbers that is found to work in keeping MoldeVort trapped on the board? Options: A. 1, 2, 3, 4, B. 1, 3, 4, 5, C. 2, 3, 4, 5, D. 1, 2, 4, 5 Correct Option: B
Question 8: How does the player's strategy change if MoldeVort says the number 4? Options: A. The player moves MoldeVort to a space that is 4 units away, B. The player moves MoldeVort to a space that is 3 units away, C. The player keeps MoldeVort on the same color by moving the length of a row or column, D. The player lets MoldeVort escape Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the benefit of considering the symmetry of the board in developing a strategy? Options: A. It allows the player to focus on a single corner of the board, B. It enables the player to reduce the problem to just three types of spaces, C. It makes it easier to calculate distances on the board, D. It helps the player to ignore the inside spaces on the board Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the ultimate outcome of the player's strategy, according to the transcript? Options: A. MoldeVort escapes and the player loses, B. The player traps MoldeVort indefinitely, C. The player keeps MoldeVort contained until help arrives, D. The game ends in a draw Correct Option: C

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The evil wizard MoldeVort 
has been trying to kill you for years, and today it looks like 
he’s going to succeed. But your friends are on their way, 
and if you can survive until they arrive, they should be able to help stop him. The evil wizard’s protective charms 
ward off every spell you know, so in an act of desperation 
you throw the only object in reach at him: Pythagoras’s cursed chessboard. It works, but with a catch. MoldeVort starts in one corner 
of the 5x5 board. You have a few minutes to choose 
four distinct positive whole numbers. MoldeVort gets to say one of them, 
and if you can pick a square on the board whose center is exactly 
that distance away, the curse will force him 
to move to that spot. Then he’ll have to choose 
any of the four numbers, and the process repeats until 
you can’t keep him inside the board with legal moves. Then he’ll break free of the spell 
and almost certainly kill you. What four numbers can you choose 
to keep MoldeVort trapped by your spell long enough for help to arrive? 
And what’s your strategy? Pause the video to figure it out yourself. Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 The trick here is to keep MoldeVort 
where you want him. And one way to figure out how to do that is to play out the game 
as MoldeVort would: always trying to escape. You’re dealing with a relatively 
small board, so the numbers can’t be too big. Let’s start by trying 1, 2, 3, 4 
to see what happens. Moldevort could escape those numbers
in just three moves. By saying 2, then 3, he would force you to let him into one
of the middle points of the grid, and then a 4 would break him free. But that means you’ll need to allow
a number larger than 4, which is the distance from one end 
of a row to another. How is that even possible? Through diagonal moves. There are, in fact, points that are 
distance 5 from each other, which we know thanks 
to the Pythagorean Theorem. That states that the squares 
of the sides of a right triangle add up to the square of its hypotenuse. One of the most famous 
Pythagorean triples is 3, 4, 5, and that triangle is hiding all over 
your chessboard. So if MoldeVort was here, and he said 5,
you could move him to these spaces. There’s another insight that will help. The board is very symmetrical: 
If MoldeVort is in a corner, it doesn’t really matter 
to you which corner it is. So we can think of the corners 
as being functionally the same, and color them all blue. Similarly, the spaces neighboring 
the corners behave the same as each other, and we’ll make them red. Finally, the midpoints of the sides 
are a third type. So instead of having to develop a strategy for each of the 16 spaces 
on the outside of the board, we can reduce the problem to just three. Meanwhile, all the inside spaces 
are bad for us, because if MoldeVort ever reaches one, he’ll be able to say any number 
larger than 3 and go free. Orange spaces are trouble too, 
since any number except 1, 2, or 4 would take him to an inside space 
or off the board. So orange is out and you’ll need 
to keep him on blue and red. That means 2 is bad, since it could take MoldeVort 
to orange on the first turn. But the four other smallest numbers, 
1, 3, 4, and 5, might work. Let’s try them and see what happens. If MoldeVort says 1, you can make 
him go from blue to red or red to blue. And the same works if he says 3. Thanks to our diagonals, 
this is even true if he says 5. If he says 4, you can keep him 
on the color he’s already on by moving the length of a row or column. So these four numbers work! Even if your friends don’t get here 
right away, you’ll be able to keep 
the world’s most evil wizard contained for as long as you need.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many numbers do you need to pick to start the enchantment?
Options: A. 2, B. 3, C. 4, D. 5
Correct Option: C

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How is distance measured on the chessboard?
Options: A. Straight line distances from the center of each square., B. By the number of moves it would take a King to get from one square to another., C. By the number of moves it would take a Rook to get from one square to another., D. Based on the number of all possible routes between squares.
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:

**Transcript**:
these word tales all make the same sound tick o tickle metal metal trav ul travel so how do you know which one to use l e is used 75 percent of the time so if you aren't sure try this one first if the word still doesn't look right try a l it's the next most common so when do you use el after the letters m n r v w and this is how you remember them most there's a camel with an m there's a tunnel there's a travel with a beanie excuse me what about these ones a l is coming after an m and an n not e l these are exceptions they have broken the rule but i can help you remember them signal my personal animal you

Correct Option: D

Question 3: If a word doesn't look right when using "le", what is the next most common alternative to try? Options: A. Using "al", B. Using "el", C. Using "il", D. Using "ol" Correct Option: B
Question 4: After which letters is "el" typically used? Options: A. M, N, R, V, W, B. A, E, I, O, U, C. C, D, F, G, H, D. J, K, L, P, Q Correct Option: A

Question 6: What are some exceptions to the rule of using "el" after the letters M and N? Options: A. Signal and animal, B. Travel and tunnel, C. Camel and cart, D. Whale and wish Correct Option: A

Question 8: How can you remember the exceptions to the rule of using "el" after the letters M and N? Options: A. By creating a story, B. By making a list, C. By visualizing a personal connection, D. By using a mnemonic device Correct Option: C

So you can impress your friends with your spelling skills, C. So you can save time when writing or typing, D. So you can make an educated guess when you're unsure Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
when three consonants get together they make a gang a gang of three finding a gang of three in a word helps you break it into smaller chunks making it easier to read and spell here are some more consonants that make a gang of three thr o throw spr ing spring shrink splat ash splash there are six different gangs to look out for for we're the toughest gang of three around here now you're not we're tougher than you we're the toughest gang over here no we are so watch out for the gang of three they can help you break words into smaller chunks

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which group of letters are NOT considered a "gang of three?"
Options: A. thr, B. scr, C. str, D. smr
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What happens when three consonants come together in a word? Options: A. They make the word harder to read., B. They make a "gang of three"., C. They change the word's meaning., D. They separate the word into individual letters. Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the benefit of finding a "gang of three" in a word? Options: A. It makes the word longer., B. It changes the word's pronunciation., C. It helps break the word into smaller chunks., D. It makes the word more difficult to spell. Correct Option: C
Question 3: Which of the following words contains the "gang of three" "spr"? Options: A. Throw, B. Spring, C. Shrink, D. Splat Correct Option: B
Question 4: How many different "gangs of three" are mentioned in the transcript? Options: A. 3, B. 4, C. 5, D. 6 Correct Option: D
Question 5: What is the main idea of the transcript? Options: A. To introduce a new vocabulary word., B. To explain a reading strategy., C. To discuss the importance of grammar., D. To analyze a literary text. Correct Option: B
Question 6: If you encounter a word with the letters "spl" together, what might you do to make it easier to read? Options: A. Separate the letters., B. Look for a prefix., C. Break the word into smaller chunks using the "gang of three"., D. Change the word's pronunciation. Correct Option: C
Question 7: Compare the words "shrink" and "splat". What do they have in common? Options: A. They both start with the letter "s"., B. They both contain a "gang of three"., C. They both end with the letter "k"., D. They both have the same meaning. Correct Option: B
Question 8: Create a new word by combining a "gang of three" with a prefix or suffix. What might be an example of such a word? Options: A. Springy, B. Throws, C. Shrinks, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 9: Evaluate the effectiveness of the "gang of three" strategy for reading and spelling. What might be a potential benefit of using this strategy? Options: A. It can make words more confusing., B. It can help readers recognize patterns in words., C. It can make words longer., D. It can change the word's meaning. Correct Option: B
Question 10: Justify the importance of recognizing "gangs of three" in words. Why might this be a useful skill for readers to develop? Options: A. It can help readers understand the word's meaning., B. It can make words more interesting., C. It can help readers break words into smaller chunks, making them easier to read and spell., D. It can change the word's pronunciation. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not an exact match, but Question 3 has some similarities. However, it does not ask which group of letters are NOT considered a "gang of three." 

A more suitable match would be a generated MCQ that asks about identifying a group of letters that are not a "gang of three" or has options that include a combination of letters that do not form a valid "gang of three." Unfortunately, none of the provided generated MCQs exactly match this criteria.
